stage.name: Systematic
stage.description: Systematically advancing key aspects of digital rights based on some priority areas with rare instances of digital rights being violated.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Clear strength in respecting and protecting digital rights with all key systemic elements in place. Minimal instances of rights violations.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Clear strength in respecting and protecting privacy online  with all key systemic elements in place. Minimal instances of rights violations.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Technology embraced: Reduced gap, high literacy.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Cultivated: Schools teach, tech equipped curriculum.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Advanced: Complex services, reduced divide.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Engaged: Tech shapes decisions, ethics guide communication.

stage.name: Systematic
stage.description: Growing access, exclusion gaps.

stage.name: Systematic
stage.description: Rudimentary: Urban-focused high-speed coverage.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Open: Similar access, recognized barriers, free access points.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Embedded, administrative integration, emerging tech.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Strategic: Inclusive vision, some shared adoption.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Integrated: Widespread skills, central strategy, metrics-driven.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Integrated digitalization: Centralized, redesigned, data-centric.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Advanced: Substantive laws, strong enforcement.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Promotion: Budget support, growing practice.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Resourced: Legal resources, intl. standards.

stage.name: Opportunistic
stage.description: Growing tech: Digital finance, moderate tech business.

stage.name: Basic
stage.description: Adverse: Limited tech adoption, unfavorable conditions.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Integrated IDs, digital wallets, accessible data.

stage.name: Transformational
stage.description: Transformational: Widespread digital payments, local currencies.

stage.name: Differentiating
stage.description: Integrated: Govt-business linked IDs, data protection.

People.Definition: No citizen left behind in digital support
People.Basic: Limited exposure: Cultural aversion, minimal tech use.
People.Opportunistic: Limited literacy: Digital gap, basic use.
People.Systematic: Growing acceptance: Basic literacy, more complex tasks.
People.Differentiating: Technology embraced: Reduced gap, high literacy.
People.Transformational: Digital society: No gap, tech ingrained in society.

People.Definition: Ability to use digital technology of all parts of society (all regions, age groups, genders); particularly of traditionally marginalized groups of society (refugees and migrants, women and youth, persons with disabilities and special needs, older people,
People.Basic: Elite: Educated, skilled minority. Digital divide persists.
People.Opportunistic: Private: Basic skills, some schools, company training.
People.Systematic: Elective: Basic skills widespread, optional school learning.
People.Differentiating: Cultivated: Schools teach, tech equipped curriculum.
People.Transformational: Widespread: Universal skills, adult centers, industry shift, integrated education.

People.Definition: Use of digital technology by different levels of society, financial inclusiveness, e-commerce activity, information access trends.
People.Basic: Basic: Tech for leisure, low access and adoption.
People.Opportunistic: Transactional: Moderate use, gaps in access.
People.Systematic: Intermediate: Complex actions, info access, tech ownership.
People.Transformational: Proficient: Comprehensive, universal access, reduced divide.

People.Definition: Understanding and mitigating harm inflicted by digital such as addiction, cyberbullying, disinformation, physical impacts.
People.Basic: Resistant: Low tech adoption, change incentives lacking.
People.Systematic: Accepting: Trial-error, active use, known channels.
People.Differentiating: Enthusiastic: Open, innovative, motivated tech adoption.
People.Transformational: Advocating: Full tech integration, societal reshaping.

People.Basic: Restricted: Tech not for citizen-govt interaction, voice exclusion.
People.Opportunistic: Volunteerism: Tech aids activism, accountability via volunteers.
People.Systematic: Community: Tech solves local issues, citizen decision influence.
People.Differentiating: Engaged: Tech shapes decisions, ethics guide communication.
People.Transformational: Participative: Integrated civic platforms, inclusive discourse, media outlets, encouraged participation.

Digital Public Infrastructure.Definition: Foundational digital catalysts are overarching digital systems which can accelerate progress in all parts of the digital transformation.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Basic: Paper IDs, traditional payments, siloed data.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Opportunistic: Basic IDs, early digital payments, limited sharing.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Systematic: Digital IDs, mobile banking, online data sharing.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Differentiating: Integrated IDs, digital wallets, accessible data.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Transformational: Beneficial ID/banking, widespread payments, open data.

Digital Public Infrastructure.Definition: Digital payments ecosystem which includes digital financial service providers, digital financial services, provider support services and enablers (e.g., platforms, agents, processors), regional and global interoperability.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Basic: Traditional: Cash, checks dominate, rare digital payments.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Opportunistic: Changing: Digital access, cards, online banking, cashless.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Systematic: Systematic: Prepaid, mobile money, no bank account.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Transformational: Transformational: Widespread digital payments, local currencies.

Digital Public Infrastructure.Definition: National digital legal identity system covering the entire population; possibility to use for stakeholders to access services and for transactions.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Basic: Paper-based: Birth, marriage, land records on paper.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Differentiating: Integrated: Govt-business linked IDs, data protection.

Digital Public Infrastructure.Definition: Open government data and private data, such as registries.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Basic: Offline: No data exchange, paper-based, no systems.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Systematic: Online: Central data, info systems, infrastructure.
Digital Public Infrastructure.Transformational: Open: Optimized model, public data, structured API.

Connectivity.Definition: Soft and Hard tools to enable digital.
Availability, affordability, and quality of broadband internet access, mobile internet, mobile services and devices, electricity, etc.
Connectivity.Transformational: Extensive: Universal, high quality, reliable services.

Connectivity.Basic: Blocked: Systemic barriers exclude at-risk groups.
Connectivity.Opportunistic: Restricted: Lower tech access, systemic barriers.
Connectivity.Systematic: Limited: Consistently lower access, ignored differentiation.
Connectivity.Differentiating: Open: Similar access, recognized barriers, free access points.
Connectivity.Transformational: Universal: Equal access, acknowledged barriers, full benefits.

Government.Basic: Limited: Paper bureaucracy, no funding, ad-hoc tech.
Government.Opportunistic: Initiatives in silos, limited support, no strategy.
Government.Systematic: Shared vision, limited funds, strategic planning.

Government.Basic: Reactive: No strategy, no senior support, isolated projects.
Government.Opportunistic: Informal: Scattered support, no national framework.
Government.Differentiating: Strategic: Inclusive vision, some shared adoption.
Government.Transformational: Visionary: Impactful strategy, top-level support, empowered leaders.

Government.Definition: System-based approach to ICT procurement and funding strategy/budget for digital transformation.
Government.Basic: Analogue: No skills, outsourcing, no strategy, no budget.
Government.Opportunistic: Outsourcing: Few skills, external help, partial strategy.
Government.Systematic: Digital seeds: Growing skills, some insourcing, developing strategy.
Government.Differentiating: Integrated: Widespread skills, central strategy, metrics-driven.
Government.Transformational: Digital by default: Embedded skills, centralized strategy, quantifiable objectives, long-term budget, full Digital Principles integration.

Government.Definition: Strategy/programs for digitalization of most important public services incl. in e-participation, standards for service design and delivery, overarching data governance framework, open government data strategy, data center strategy.
Government.Basic: Paper-based: No online services, in-person only.
Government.Opportunistic: Digitization: Basic digital tools, in-person main.
Government.Transformational: Smart State: Online access, optional in-person, full redesign.

Government.Basic: Closed: No info sharing, no feedback or evaluation.
Government.Opportunistic: Reactionary: Limited sharing, key stakeholder input.
Government.Systematic: Transparent: Regular info sharing, some stakeholder input.
Government.Differentiating: Participatory: Info sharing, broad input, partial KPIs.
Government.Transformational: Collaborative: Open, stakeholder partnership, robust feedback, evaluations.

Regulation.Systematic: Established: Substantive digital laws, weak enforcement.
Regulation.Transformational: Dynamic: Strong laws, justice, formal intl. cooperation.

Regulation.Basic: No recognition: No data protection, access barriers.
Regulation.Opportunistic: Regulate & forget: Ineffective legislation, no enforcement.
Regulation.Systematic: Recognition: Functional data protection authority, regulation.
Regulation.Differentiating: Promotion: Key data rights protected, enforced.
Regulation.Transformational: Dynamic Legal Framework: Enforced tailored regulation, FOI used, accessible government data.

Regulation.Basic: No recognition: Tech not policy consideration.
Regulation.Opportunistic: Regulate & forget: Uniform reg., no impact assessment.
Regulation.Systematic: Recognition: Discuss need to regulate tech impact.
Regulation.Transformational: Dynamic Legal Framework: Evolving, outcome-based, feedback loops, soft law mechanisms.

Regulation.Basic: No recognition: No IP law, static taxation, telecom monopoly.
Regulation.Opportunistic: Regulate & forget: Outdated IP law, some competition.
Regulation.Systematic: Recognition: Licensing promotes competition, balanced prices.
Regulation.Differentiating: Promotion: Adaptive taxation, national IP protection.
Regulation.Transformational: Dynamic Legal Framework: Anti-monopoly, IP protection, flexible dispute resolution.

Regulation.Basic: No recognition: No cyber crime law, unprotected infrastructure.
Regulation.Opportunistic: Regulate & forget: Developing law, seeking resources.
Regulation.Transformational: Dynamic Legal Framework: Comprehensive law, baselines, compliance, international alignment.

Regulation.Opportunistic: Regulate & forget: Limited watchdog, partial monopoly.
Regulation.Transformational: Dynamic Legal Framework: Strong watchdog, tailored legislation, price monitoring.

Regulation.Basic: Not recognized: No digital human rights.
Regulation.Transformational: Fully protected: Legal, institutional, tech safeguards.

Economy.Basic: Limited integration: Traditional finance, low tech business.
Economy.Opportunistic: Growing tech: Digital finance, moderate tech business.
Economy.Systematic: Cross-sector collab: Seed financing, wide tech business.
Economy.Differentiating: Coordinated digital: Inclusive ecosystems, efficient tech.
Economy.Transformational: Digital industry: Responsibility standards, widespread models.

Economy.Basic: Adverse: Limited tech adoption, unfavorable conditions.
Economy.Systematic: Favorable: Wide tech, improved conditions for all sectors.
Economy.Differentiating: Ecosystem formation: Majority use tech, coordinated policies.
Economy.Transformational: Ecosystem integration: Tech integrated, cooperative networks.

Economy.Basic: Emerging: Primarily physical access to financial services.
Economy.Opportunistic: Developing: Early adopters introduce basic digital services.
Economy.Systematic: Strategic: Established digital services, essential for finance.
Economy.Differentiating: Market leading: Mature digital financial services, market focus.
Economy.Transformational: People leading: Inclusive finance, public-private finance for the vulnerable.

Economy.Basic: Stagnant: Limited graduates, outdated curriculum, lack of engagement.
Economy.Opportunistic: Emergent: Improved communication, industry-academia ties, updated curriculum.
Economy.Differentiating: Interconnected: Extensive engagement, cross-sector collaboration, international events.
Economy.Transformational: Dynamic: Thriving ecosystem, comprehensive collaboration, strong IT career path, global ties.

Economy.Basic: Unaware: Lack of awareness about ethical standards in digital services.
Economy.Opportunistic: Cognizant: Awareness but limited action on ethical standards.
Economy.Systematic: Compliant: Minimum ethical compliance, external constraint view.
Economy.Transformational: Advocate: Embedded ethics, evolving standards, proactive advocacy.
